In this work, we report the synthesis of a hydrate, neon hydrate, and the observation of the structure by in situ neutron diffraction. The structure is found to be in excellent agreement with the simulation results. This work provides a new perspective on the structure of ice II and opens up a new avenue for the study of the structure of ice under high pressure.

Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states on algebras of observables. However, this description is not mathematically precise. We provide a precise mathematical description of quantum theory in terms of continuous linear functionals on suitable spaces of states. This description is based on a categorical approach to mathematical physics, which is independent of any particular mathematical structure on the physical objects.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to evolutionary and biomedical research. However, the evolutionary origin of this group has been elusive. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. This reduction was accompanied by the loss of key signaling pathways and transcriptional factors involved in multicellular development. These findings provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Less)

In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. In addition, climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields. We quantify the impact of these two trends on maize production and trade. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in many of the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. This variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in these countries. This instability in maize production will have important consequences for global food security.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in food consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being matched in size and digestive physiology, these species consumed different plant species and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were dissimilar in these traits. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity. (Less)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of the plastic debris, which is dominated by small particles, mostly below 1 mm. These particles are rapidly degraded into smaller fragments, which are then transported to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes. This study highlights the importance of size-selective sinks in the global fate of floating plastic debris.

Interstellar grains are the only direct evidence of the origin of the elements. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is consistent with the origin of the elements in the early universe. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This study provides a new constraint on the origin of the elements. It also provides a new perspective on the origin of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to offspring correlates with an increase in reproductive output. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. VX-765 also protected substantia nigra neurons from degeneration. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic agent for MSA. This is the first proof of concept study in a mouse model of MSA. (truncated)

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular function, including blood pressure, inflammation, and clotting. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that communicate with each other to control these functions. This study reveals the structure of the communication network between these cells. The network is surprisingly small-world, which means that the cells are connected in a way that allows rapid and robust communication between them. This structure is important for the endothelium to efficiently control cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor and respond to the pandemic. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the data that are available are often not in a common format. We describe the data sources and signals in the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This allows researchers to easily combine and analyze the data, and to track revisions to historical data. The data and software are available to the public, and we hope that they will be useful to researchers and decision makers.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for health. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of natural products from anaerobic fungi, which are a previously uncharacterized group of gut microbes. We found that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, peptides, and polyketides. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the microbiome and could be used as a source of natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and suggests a potential therapeutic approach for social anxiety disorder. (Less)

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the current design paradigm is limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of structures. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the development of a digital library of materials and structures, which are synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach. The synthesized structures are digitally synthesized with multiple materials and optimized to achieve the desired responses. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable responses. The proposed strategy can be applied to a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is a function of the developmental stage of the erythroblasts. In adults, the predominant hemoglobin is adult hemoglobin (HbA), which is expressed in the fetal-to-neonatal stage of development. In fetuses, the predominant hemoglobin is fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which is expressed in the neonatal stage of development. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), which is expressed in erythroid cells. Here we show that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the hemoglobin expression pattern in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. However, these drugs are associated with a high risk of adverse effects. In this study, we identified a mechanism of action of these drugs that may help to explain the adverse effects and to improve the safety of these drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for forest conservation in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first plan to use the concept of multiple ecosystem types. We show that the NWFP was not effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has been effective in halting clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has also failed to halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT highstands are observed during times of high eccentricity. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with reduced sleep duration and quality, and with adverse consequences on general health. The biological effects of these devices on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred ∼12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope compositions of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are consistent with a terrestrial origin. In contrast, the Os in bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania is likely derived from meteoritic sources. The YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The spherules are likely ejecta from an impact 12.9 ka ago. The Os in the spherules and their leachates is likely terrestrially derived. The Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America is the likely source of the spherules. These results support the impact hypothesis for the YDB.

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, including lymphoproliferation, autoantibody production, and organ-specific autoimmunity. This was not fatal, but was accompanied by a shift in the balance of Treg cells and Th cells. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its role in the development of autoimmunity in adult mice is different from that in congenital deficiency.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes, including those encoding microbial enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved controversial beetle relationships and revealed that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of angiosperms. We also found that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These findings provide insights into the evolution of beetles and the origin of plant-feeding habits, which are key to understanding the origin of life. (Less)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the efficacy of vaccines and approved antibodies. Here, we demonstrate the utility of a deep learning algorithm in improving the neutralizing activity of an antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results suggest that this algorithm can be used to optimize antibodies for improved activity against emerging variants. This approach can potentially be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This approach can potentially be used to address the challenges of viral evolution and the development of antiviral therapeutics and vaccines.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly phagocytic. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of C1q, a protein that may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses, in the brain. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may explain the increased risk of APOE4 carriers for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase of iron is unlikely to occur in the core, and the nucleation of the metastable, body-centered, cubic (bcc) phase is much more likely. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core and the structure of the core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addictive behaviors. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might be a critical target for the treatment of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for predicting the next word in a sentence are also the most accurate at predicting the brain responses to those sentences in humans. This suggests that the same neural and computational mechanisms are used to understand language in both humans and machines.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This paradox is resolved by establishing a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The pandemic’s origins are hotly debated, but the scientific community’s response to the pandemic is not. It is increasingly common to hear scientists argue that the pandemic is caused by people’s inability to understand exponential growth. They point to a classic psychological experiment published 45 years prior to the first case of COVID-19, which they claim is a demonstration of this inability. We show that this experiment is flawed in multiple ways, including its failure to control for experimenter expectations. We also show that the experiment’s critical design flaws were not only overlooked at the time, but also, in hindsight, undermine the conclusion the experiment’s authors drew from it.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a Mexican patient and compared it with that of M. leprae. The genomes are similar in size and synteny, and have undergone extensive reductive evolution. M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of the two leprosy bacilli and may be the more ancient pathogen. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Less)

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two main quantities that are not conserved in time in quantum mechanics. Therefore, they are the two main quantities that are not conserved in time in quantum mechanics. In the last decade, the study of the time evolution of entanglement has led to the discovery of a number of remarkable results. However, these results were available only for systems that are not interacting. Here, we show that the dynamics of interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which allows us to derive a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and no vaccine is available for children under 12 years of age. In addition, the pandemic is expected to continue for at least another year, and the need for a vaccine for this age group is urgent. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated and protects hamsters from lethal challenge with wild-type virus. This vaccine candidate is expected to be highly protective in children and, therefore, can be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is poorly understood. We developed a mathematical model to study the history of plague transmission by human ectoparasites. We found that human ectoparasites were the primary vector of plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This contradicts the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results suggest that plague was spread by humans, which may have led to the spread of the disease to new regions.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is biased by the fact that brains are bigger in bigger animals. Here, we show that this is not the case for amniotes, the group that includes birds and mammals. We show that the evolution of brain size is not only biased by body size but also by the number of neurons. This is important because it allows us to see the evolution of brain size in a less biased way.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the role of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (truncated)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanism is critical for ADF to efficiently sever highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell junctions. Our findings provide a mechanism for how ADF can regulate the mechanical properties of the actin cytoskeleton. This mechanism may be important for understanding the role of ADF in a variety of biological processes.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in response to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the brain may be a potential target for interventions aimed at reducing food intake.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, its settlement history is still debated. Here, we use a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its genomic diversity. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a new tool to study the history of human populations. (Less)

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting in person. This is a form of emotional contagion, and it is not limited to the laboratory. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a common feature of all organisms. In this study, we show that the presence of one common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest impact on the translation of the mRNA. We find that the presence of Ψ can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition to a codon, and can increase the rate of peptide synthesis from an mRNA. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA can have a modest impact on protein synthesis. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA can have a modest impact on protein synthesis.

The feeling that one’s life is meaningful and worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive health and behavioral outcomes, including better physical and mental health, more favorable biomarkers, healthier lifestyles, and less loneliness and disability. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, education, and health. Longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is associated with positive changes in health and behavior over time. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying drivers remain unclear. Here, we use a quantitative model of the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the unique energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. It replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. The mechanism of this temperature-dependent growth is not known. We show that mouse airway cells preferentially mount an antiviral defense response at core body temperature relative to nasal cavity temperature. This response is essential for temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (truncated)

The bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients and other individuals. It is also one of the most difficult pathogens to eradicate from the environment. This is partly due to its ability to attach to surfaces, which allows it to persist in the environment and to recolonize the body of infected individuals. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This is a new mechanism of surface sensing that is distinct from the classical mechanisms used by bacteria to sense the environment. Our findings have important implications for the control of this important pathogen. Understanding the mechanisms used by bacteria to sense surfaces could lead to the development of new strategies for controlling their persistence in the environment and in the body of infected individuals. This could be particularly important for the control of this pathogen, which is currently difficult to eradicate from the environment and from the body of infected individuals.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced, and that the application of pesticides should be restricted to the minimum necessary to protect crops.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the blood of free-living white-tailed deer. This discovery has important implications for the persistence of the pandemic and the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology and evolution of the virus.

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of hydropower dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein, which are toxic to neurons. However, the earliest pathological changes in AD are not restricted to Aβ and tau, but also include a complex immune response. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of immune factors, even in the absence of Aβ plaques. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may therefore represent a potential therapeutic target for AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, its origin and early history remain unresolved issues. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are abundant in response to stress, have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. In this study, we show that one of the predominant enzymes involved in decapping those RNAs, a pyrophosphohydrolase, preferentially removes the cap of the dinucleoside tetraphosphate. This enzyme, which is normally inactive in response to stress, is activated by the presence of the cap, and the cap is recognized by a mechanism distinct from the one used to recognize other 5′ termini. This unique recognition mechanism positions the phosphate of the cap for cleavage, resulting in the production of triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which cells respond to stress and may have important implications for the control of gene expression in response to environmental changes. Sepsis is a major cause of mortality worldwide. Although the immune system is activated in response to the infection, it also becomes dysfunctional, leading to the development of severe sepsis. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, can restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to improve the immune response in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without defects or impurities. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly without defects or impurities. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the role of the immune system in the defense against bacteria and viruses is less clear. In this study, we show that a small peptide, NCR044, isolated from the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula, has antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of this peptide is unique and different from that of other known antifungal peptides. This work provides a new insight into the role of the immune system in the defense against plant fungal pathogens. It also provides a new class of antifungal peptides that can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is expected to be useful for the control of plant fungal diseases in the field and postharvest. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent to which the female contributes to the process of fertilization is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female contributes to the life history of sperm, and that these contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of Drosophila sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to the platelet receptor, glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα), and that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster binding. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD and may be relevant to other diseases in which the binding of a protein to a receptor is important.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in human health has only recently been explored. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and provides a resource for future studies. We analyzed over 10,000 metagenomic samples, and found that viruses are prevalent in the human body. We also found that many viruses are associated with disease. This resource will be useful for future studies of the human virome, and will provide a foundation for future studies of the role of viruses in human disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean, the period of time when life first emerged, has been the subject of much debate. This study provides a new perspective on this issue by using the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean. The results of this study are consistent with the surface temperature of the Earth decreasing over geological time.

K+ channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body and are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes. They are also important targets for drug development. The K+ channel KCNK15, also known as BK, is a large-conductance calcium-activated potassium channel that is involved in a variety of physiological processes. It is a major contributor to the resting membrane potential of the inner ear hair cells and is involved in hearing and balance. We found that BK channels have two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This finding may help to explain the unique properties of BK channels and may be useful in drug development. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The Plasmodium parasite infects the red blood cell (RBC) and invades the host blood vessel, where it can cause severe damage. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the parasite’s surface proteins in this process is not fully understood. Here, we show that the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is the first time that a parasite protein has been shown to alter the biophysical properties of the host cell, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This finding has major implications for our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Less)

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without defects or impurities, and that its electronic and optical properties can be tuned by strain. This opens up opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza-associated morbidity and mortality. Our study may also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapeutics. This article is protected

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is not supported by neuroimaging studies. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence, but suddenly increases when words are merged into phrases. This suggests that the brain performs a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. We also show that the model of phrase construction provides a better fit to the data than models based solely on sequential probability. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system. (Less)

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently, which may be important for tissue-specific regulation. This is a common feature in many biological systems, and it is important to understand the mechanisms that underlie this.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. It is also a site of action for electrical or optogenetic stimulation of neurons that induces vigorous eating in sated animals. We have characterized the circuitry downstream of LH stimulation. Stimulation of LH neurons causes food approach and eating, and this effect is blocked by lesions of peri-LH GABA neurons or peri-LH dopamine neurons. This system may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen to crops, thus providing a sustainable solution to the global nitrogen crisis. Here, we have developed a system for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This system allows for the tight control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley.

The Peruvian Amazon is one of the most deforested regions in the world. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected communities in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s small sample size and the difficulty of attributing deforestation to the program. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb web of the spider is a hearing organ that is also part of the body. The web is a highly sensitive acoustic antenna that can detect the motion of the air particles caused by sound. The spider can use the web to localize the sound source and even to remotely detect the presence of prey. The spider can also adjust and regenerate its web to improve its hearing performance. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors. It also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of hearing. (Show more)

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. Aerosols affect the hydrologic cycle, contributing to water and food security. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing pollution particles liberates 0.51 °C and all particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and devastate economies. Vaccines are needed to end the pandemic, but the current vaccines are not available to all the world’s population. We engineered a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for inclusion in a vaccine. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be expressed in bacteria, which is a cost-effective and scalable manufacturing platform. This engineered RBD can be used in a vaccine to provide protection against the pandemic.

The role of ALK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is well established. However, the ligand(s) that activate ALK in vivo are unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like proteins (DrALKals) are ligands for zebrafish ALK and human ALK. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/ALKL receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings have important implications for the role of ALK in human cancer and for the development of zebrafish models for human diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the deadliest outbreaks in human history. The emergence of Y. pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established story, but the details of its evolution and ecology during this formative period are still poorly understood. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes from across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this lineage over time. Our results reveal a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, and the potential for future adaptation. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Implications for psychology, sociology, and public policy are discussed.

The conversion of grasslands to agricultural production has led to massive emissions of carbon (C) to the atmosphere. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has been the primary driver of this problem. However, the use of conservation practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and the addition of manure, can mitigate this problem. We show that these practices can increase the storage of carbon in the soil, but the magnitude of the effect depends on the type of practice and the region of the country. These results highlight the importance of the management of grasslands in the mitigation of climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used this framework to rank the risk of spillover of 887 viruses from animals to humans. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is the reward that flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the reward’s quality, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of a red pigment in nectar, which is likely to be important for the attraction of vertebrate pollinators. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the ecology and evolution of flowering plants.

We present a study of the genetic structure of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our results indicate that they had a very high genetic diversity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that some of them had artificial skull deformations, which may have been related to their genetic ancestry. Our results suggest that the genetic diversity of women in this period was higher than previously thought, and that they may have contributed to the shaping of the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origins of MERS-CoV and the mechanisms of its cross-species transmission. They also provide a basis for developing effective countermeasures against

The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. The emergence of new pathogens, such as COVID-19, is a particular concern in resource-scarce settings. The rapid identification of pathogens is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA from febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using unbiased metagenomic sequencing in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The results of this study can inform the development of similar surveillance efforts in other resource-scarce settings. (Less)

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by a complex of DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) and the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the dynamics of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of pol δ in cancer and other diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this paper, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate nucleic acids in the absence of proteins. This is a major step toward the creation of a functional RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, could reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new treatment strategy for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The existence of a fungal natural product that binds copper and impacts cellular copper content is surprising, as is the existence of a fungal natural product that has antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the existence of fungal natural products that bind and impact cellular copper content may be more common than currently appreciated.

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a drill sample of laminated mudstone at the base of the Gale crater sequence in the Spirit rover region of Mars is significant because it is the first detection of this polymorph in a sedimentary environment. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment suggests that the sediment source region was a high-temperature environment, such as a silicic volcanic region, and that the sediment was transported to the depositional site. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and amorphous silica in the sediment suggests that the sediment was deposited in a shallow, alkaline lake or other aqueous environment. The presence of magnetite and mixed-cation salts/oxides in the sediment suggests that the sediment was deposited in a relatively warm, alkaline environment. The presence of anhydrite in the sediment suggests that the sediment was deposited in a relatively dry environment. Frost events are a major threat to plants and animals in the temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in response to climate warming. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are adapted to the local frost risk, and that these strategies are changing in response to climate warming. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of this disease is unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be converted to Th1-like cells, which are required for the development of colitis. Th17 cells can also provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to this disease may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is also driven by environmental factors. The disease process is complex, and there is no animal model that recapitulates all the features of the disease. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable the study of the disease process and the development of therapeutics. This method will also enable the study of the role of astrocytes in ALS, which are known to be involved in the disease, but difficult to study in animal models. This will lead to the development of new therapeutics.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. However, the mechanisms by which Anaplasma influences the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors and may have implications for vector control. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is associated with the origin of flight. However, the history of the tail in the early evolution of birds is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians. Here, we describe a basal member of the group, Jinguofortis perplexus, which adds important information about the early evolution of the tail and the origin of flight in birds. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One of the reasons for this is that the climate system is a coupled system, meaning that its behavior is affected by its interactions with other parts of the Earth system. In this paper, we show that the interactions between the atmosphere and the oceans can be important in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, including blue-green. This phenomenon, called chlorosis, is associated with the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times in anurans, and that it is associated with the presence of a specific group of serpins. These serpins bind biliverdin, and their presence is necessary for the occurrence of chlorosis. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also provides a tool for the study of the evolution of serpins and their function. (Less)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is increased in BCSCs and is HIF-dependent. ALKBH5 expression is required for hypoxia-induced enrichment of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 mediates the enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. This study provides insight into the role of m6A modification in breast cancer and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost transparent. The source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to study the history of parchment and the development of the book. (Less)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is poorly constrained, and the role of trigger and kill mechanisms is uncertain. We report the age of the extinction at 251.9–251.8 Ma, a time when the carbon cycle was highly variable. This age is based on a precise and accurate U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds at the base of the global extinction. The age of the extinction is consistent with the onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle, and the carbon cycle volatility persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. This work provides a precise age for the extinction and establishes a time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium has not been fully elucidated. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0 Å resolution. We find that the D614G mutation has led to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a basis for understanding the impact of mutations on the structure and function of the spike glycoprotein. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.
