The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the origin of chemical phenomena, such as the formation of compounds under pressure. However, there is no clear understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure. Here, we propose a new way to calculate the chemical properties of atoms, which is based on the chemical potential of the electron. We find that the chemical properties of atoms change significantly under pressure, and we can predict and even explain many chemical phenomena under pressure. This work provides a new perspective on the origin of chemical phenomena and a new way to study the chemical properties of atoms.

We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has important implications for the carbon cycle, as well as for the role of fire in regulating other ecosystem functions. Our results suggest that, in the absence of climate change, global fire activity has been increasing over the last century. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and development. In this study, we show that the symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its luminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is regulated by the cyclic delivery of a single glycan. This glycan is synthesized by the host, which also delivers it to the symbiont in a specific manner. The glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the pH of the host’s symbiotic crypts. This pH change, in turn, enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. Our results suggest that the delivery of glycans may be a general mechanism for the regulation of symbiotic interactions. (Less)

The study of topics in text data is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that combines advances in theoretical machine learning with word embedding to model topics in text. We apply our method to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. This approach can be extended to many domains and can be used to identify latent patterns in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. These results suggest that the Black Death was not the consequence of a single introduction, but rather the consequence of multiple introductions, each of which was followed by a delay of 15 ± 1 y before the disease became established in

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are important components of marine food webs. They are also a popular attraction in aquaria and are frequently used in research. In recent years, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids on the Pacific coast of North America. This disease is characterized by rapid mortality, and the cause of the disease is unknown. Here, we show that the disease is caused by a virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML patients is very poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibody-based therapy in AML. This approach may

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestries. We also found that the admixture happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across Madagascar reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the evolution of human diversity in the Indian Ocean. (Less)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While most sRNAs are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. We also show that the RNA base pairs with the promoter of two genes and interferes with their regulation. These findings demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of sRNAs compete. This is an important finding because it suggests that the two functions of sRNAs may be interdependent.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the efficacy of vaccines and approved antibodies. Here, we demonstrate the utility of a deep learning algorithm in improving the neutralizing activity of an antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results suggest that this algorithm can be used to optimize antibodies for improved activity against emerging variants. This approach can potentially be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This approach can potentially be used to address the challenges of viral evolution and the development of antiviral therapeutics and vaccines.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and categorical. We show how to convert this information into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict yields. We show that the original data are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great scientific interest and societal importance. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of life is a central question in biology. The origin of plastids, organelles that are found in all eukaryotic organisms, is a key step in the origin of life. Plastids are thought to have evolved from photosynthetic bacteria, but the origin of parasitic lifestyles is poorly understood. We show that the transition to parasitic lifestyles is linked to a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, is a story of science, history, and the human condition.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which have remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here, we show that the two enzymes are part of a single protein family, and that the evolution of the cyclase has been shaped by the presence or absence of oxygen.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a key kinase that is activated by a variety of stimuli, including proinflammatory cytokines. However, the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remains unclear. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated the disease. In addition, ASK1 in astrocytes plays a critical role in the later stage of EAE, suggesting that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings provide insights into the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest period in the state’s instrumental record and one of the most extreme droughts in the world. We show that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and wildfire risk in California and elsewhere in the world.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes. It also provides a potential target for the development of therapeutics for autism. This study is expected to contribute to the development of therapeutics for autism.

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 are associated with severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still unclear. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibited the antiviral responses of the host and facilitated viral infection. MTX had no effect on the aminopeptidase function of LTA4H and therefore did not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings may contribute to the development of novel antiviral strategies for the prevention and control of viral diseases in bats and humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting this growth. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and develop a strategy to exploit it. We identify a small molecule that inhibits the one-carbon metabolism enzymes serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2. We show that this inhibition is effective in cancer cells, and that the one-carbon donor formate can rescue cells from inhibition. However, formate is a poor inhibitor of the enzyme, and thus the inhibition is paradoxically more toxic to cancer cells than to normal cells. We show that this toxicity is rooted in defective glycine import in cancer cells, and thus a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of genes, including those that encode proteins that are highly aggregation prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusions that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be of interest to researchers in many areas, including atom optics, photonic crystals, quantum optics, and quantum information science.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still controversial. The study of Montsechia, an early flowering plant from the Cretaceous, provides new insights into the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolutionary history of viruses in order to understand their current status and potential future evolution. Here we present the genomes of ancient parvoviruses from human remains that date back to ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily for the last 25 y, and this rise is accelerating. This acceleration is consistent with the effects of climate change. The rate of sea level rise is strongly influenced by the rate of melting of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets, and the rate of warming of the climate system. The contribution of these two factors to the acceleration of sea level rise is difficult to separate, but we estimate that the contribution of the ice sheets is 0.04 ± 0.02 mm/y2.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the elderly are more likely to report pain than those in midlife. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence increases with age across birth cohorts, and this pattern is seen in each successive cohort, regardless of occupation or obesity levels. Thus, the gap in pain between the more and less educated has widened in each successive birth cohort. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, and tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme active site is a key determinant of enzyme function. However, the structure of the substrate, which is the determinant of the active site, is often unknown. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the substrate in the active site of an enzyme. This provides insight into the reaction pathway and the role of the active site in catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe coronavirus infection that has caused a large number of deaths in humans. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is currently in clinical use for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study supports the need for a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS patients. (truncated)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, which is used by the bacterium to produce light. We show that the glycan is provided only at dusk, when the squid’s immune cells migrate into the symbiotic organ. This timing is consistent with the need for the glycan to be metabolized by the bacterium, which is used to produce oxygen in the symbiotic organ. This study provides a new example of how animals can regulate the activities of their symbionts through the strategic provision of nutrients. (Less)

Suspension rates are rising in the United States, and suspensions are associated with long-term negative outcomes. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset was associated with a 50% reduction in suspensions. The intervention was scalable and cost-effective. These findings have implications for the future of American education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the replication and transcription of DNA. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and is a leading cause of biodiversity loss and water pollution. The food choices of the majority of people in high-income countries have not changed significantly in recent decades, despite the availability of more sustainable options. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a significant impact on meal selection. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available by 50% could increase the proportion of people choosing vegetarian meals by 60% in a single year. This would have important benefits for the environment and population health. The results also suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available can be achieved without a significant impact on overall sales. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of sustainable meals available in catering environments in a cost-effective way. The results have implications for the food systems of high-income countries and beyond.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to capture and sequence the surface proteome of breast epithelial cells, and have applied this to study the effects of oncogenes on the surfaceome. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics, and find massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast ballots by mail instead of going to the polls. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its rapid spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated, at least in part, by corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1). We also show that CRFR1 is expressed by astrocytes and that CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε in astrocytes. This leads to an up-regulation of AQP4 and ET-1 expression, which contributes to edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Less)

The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially. The sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is also growing exponentially. This paper describes a new challenge that this revolution presents to science. It is the challenge of “selective inference.” We must be able to declare significant only the strongest associations that we find in our data.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel, and their dysfunction is associated with many diseases, including atherosclerosis and stroke. Transplantation of ECs is a promising therapeutic approach for these diseases. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces the formation of functional ECs in vitro and in vivo. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This approach may be useful for the treatment of ischemic disorders. (Show more)

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In the past decade, two additional RTKs have been identified, which are involved in cancer development. These are anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). Here, we show that zebrafish, a model organism, can be used to study the physiological role of these two RTKs. We show that zebrafish deficient in Ltk display a severe defect in iridophore patterning of the eye and body. This defect is mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system to study the role of RTKs in development and cancer. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular basis of T2D is well known, the mechanisms that regulate the progression of T2D remain to be elucidated. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of viral RNA into virions is a fundamental process in all viruses, but the molecular details of this process are still unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of interacting RNA segments. Our results provide a molecular understanding of the selective packaging of influenza A virus genomes. This knowledge is important for understanding the evolution of influenza A viruses and for the development of antiviral strategies. (Less)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The development of these lesions is a multistep process that is initiated by the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in the endothelium. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. YAP/TAZ knockdown significantly attenuated the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation, whereas overexpression of constitutively active YAP was sufficient to promote EC proliferation and inflammation. Wildfire is a natural process that is important for the health of ecosystems and the economy. However, wildfire is also a hazard that can cause significant damage to property and loss of life. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with economic and demographic factors. Specifically, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a demonstration of the power of computer vision methods to study urban change. We hope that this work will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the recent outbreak has prompted global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, allowing for characterization of the disease process. We also assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment, showing that the treatment can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can inform the design of clinical trials and the development of antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the mechanisms underlying bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In this study, we show that the epithelium is also a critical regulator of the microbiome. We identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the growth of intestinal tumors. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain intestinal homeostasis. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis.

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we found that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. This enhanced expression of ROR1 was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are important in the regulation of breast cancer stemness. Furthermore, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (truncated)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still a matter of debate. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that plausibly contributed to the onset of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries catches, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that river basins with high biodiversity also have high catches. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is mainly determined by the negative electrode materials. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity of neurons is severely diminished, and regeneration is completely lost in the adult. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the DLK-1/DLK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite, and it is enhanced by disrupting activity-dependent calcium signaling. These connections suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of genes involved in regeneration. Our study also reveals a form of regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS that is similar to lesion conditioning, a phenomenon in which the adult CNS regenerates robustly in response to physical lesion of a sensory neurite.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the transmission of genetic information. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, a model organism for the study of evolution and development. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions experiencing intense recombination, and others experiencing little. These patterns are reminiscent of those observed in yeast and mice, suggesting that they are conserved features of eukaryotic evolution.

The resting brain is organized in functional networks, which are implicated in a variety of cognitive and neurological functions. The present study provides a detailed description of the resting brain organization in health and disease, based on the analysis of metabolic fluctuations in functional MRI. The results provide a framework for the interpretation of functional neuroimaging studies, and may be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This modification is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. The presence of NAD-RNA on specific subsets of mRNAs suggests that this modification may have a role in regulating mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The molecular mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also suggest that epigenetic modifications may be a target for therapeutic interventions to improve metabolic memory and prevent microvascular complications in people with diabetes.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder, which is characterized by alterations in the composition of the gut microbiota and in the activity of the microbiota. The aim of the present study was to explore whether changes in gut permeability are linked to gut-microbiota composition and activity in alcohol-dependent subjects. We also investigated whether gut dysfunction is associated with the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Finally, we tested the reversibility of the biological and behavioral parameters after a short-term detoxification program. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence, which may be important psychological factors of relapse. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the volatile chemicals it produces. These chemicals are synthesized from a variety of precursors, including amino acids. However, the biosynthetic pathways for many of these compounds are unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of a group of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor, cysteine, to produce a wide range of volatile chemicals. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and will be of interest to researchers in a variety of disciplines. (Less)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of both biodiversity loss and environmental warming together, rather than separately. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of both biodiversity loss and environmental warming together, rather than separately.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large population of neurons that fire in a grid-like pattern when the animal is moving in a particular direction. These neurons are thought to form a map of the local environment, but the organization of this map is not known. Here, we used a new technique to record from many neurons in MEC while the animal was freely moving. We found that the grid cells are strongly connected to each other, but weakly connected to other cell types. This suggests that grid cells form a network that is largely distinct from other cell types in MEC. Our results have important implications for understanding the formation of spatial representations in the brain. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and endogenous factors. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) protein, which is known to be a key regulator of flowering, is able to synchronize the flowering of host and parasite plants. This is an example of how parasites may have evolved to synchronize their life cycles with those of their hosts, which may be advantageous for the parasite to optimize its fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with the degeneration of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and with the loss of their innervation by the nigrostriatal neurons. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. These units, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are formed by tightly intertwined striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites. They are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether they feel connected. This signal is used by people to gauge the quality of their connections with others, and by third-party listeners to gauge the quality of their connections with each other.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their automaticity is governed by a complex interplay between the membrane and store-operated Ca2+ entry. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well understood. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, in wild-type rice plants. This effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact synergistically in defense against insect herbivory. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may contribute to the development of sustainable pest management strategies. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still unclear. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical challenge for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures, which are able to overcome the cell wall and deliver the cargo into the nucleus. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the scientific community interested in the development of plant-based therapeutics. (Less)

Eutrophication is one of the greatest threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of eutrophication is driven by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused almost exclusively on the largest watersheds, despite their small proportion of the total load. We show that small tributaries of large lakes can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. Our findings suggest that small watersheds may be a significant driver of coastal eutrophication, and that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include smaller watersheds. This could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of complex systems in the real world, where the dynamics of the system are biased toward rare events that are difficult to achieve.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the dynamics of cortical microcircuitry, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We validate a dynamic model of cortical microcircuitry and show that it can explain the effects of NMDAR-Abs on cortical dynamics. We then use this model to show that NMDAR-Abs can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities even when the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs may be a consequence of the underlying autoimmune disease, rather than a direct effect of the antibodies. This may have important implications for the treatment of these patients. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, especially in the context of the Earth system. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the Earth system response to abrupt climate change and can be used to better understand the history of abrupt climate change.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations in Indonesia, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is involved in the regulation of the size and shape of the plasma membrane, the formation of the primary site of vesicle attachment to the cell surface, and the regulation of the trafficking of the secretory vesicles. The exocyst complex is conserved from bacteria to humans, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex and offers a valuable tool for studying the regulation of this process. This study offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles are segregating at a single locus, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the presence of reactive oxygen species (ROS) is a hallmark of the photoreceptor cell. The retina also contains iron, which is a key component of ROS-generating enzymes and redox active proteins. In this study, we show that the presence of iron in the retina can promote the formation of reactive oxygen species and the photodegradation of retinal pigment epithelium-derived lipofuscin, a major contributor to age-related macular degeneration. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and other retinal diseases. (Less)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in shaping the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it leads to the loss of morphological and functional diversity. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is associated with the evolution of morphological innovations. Our findings suggest that the evolution of specialization is not only possible, but also likely to occur in other predators. This could have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of food webs, and for the design of future experiments and studies.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the origin of the derived features of the modern hand is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports this process. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and develop a strategy to exploit it. We identify a small molecule that inhibits the one-carbon metabolism enzymes serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell cancers. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and that this vulnerability is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and developed a strategy to exploit it. This strategy may be useful in the treatment of cancer.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of natural landscapes such as forests. This study has important implications for policy makers, as forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for higher output of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
